answer_html: To find another one, we can simply add a constant to the anti-derivative shown above, say \(F_2(x) = -e^{3-x} + 5\).When we differentiate, the constant will disappear, giving us the same derivative as before.
answer_latex:
To find another one, we can simply add a
constant to the anti-derivative shown above, say
$F_2(x) = -e^{3-x} + 5$.When we differentiate, the constant will
disappear, giving us the same derivative as before.
hints_html:
Recall that \(e^x\) is its own derivative.

Suppose you have one function \(f(x)\) that has a derivative of \(g(x)\). Can you think of an easy function \(h(x)\) that has derivative zero so that when you add to \(f(x)\) you get

\(\displaystyle (f(x) + h(x))' = f'(x) + h'(x) = f'(x) + 0 = g(x)\)
hints_latex: Recall that $e^x$ is its own derivative.

Suppose you have one function $f(x)$ that has a derivative of $g(x)$.
Can you think of an easy function $h(x)$ that has derivative zero so
that when you add to $f(x)$ you get

$\displaystyle (f(x) + h(x))' =  f'(x) + h'(x) = f'(x) + 0 = g(x)$
hints_raw:
Recall that <math>e^x</math> is its own derivative.
Suppose you have one function <math> f(x) </math> that has a derivative of <math> g(x) </math>. Can you think of an easy function <math> h(x) </math> that has derivative zero so that when you add to <math> f(x) </math> you get

<math> \displaystyle (f(x) + h(x))' =  f'(x) + h'(x) = f'(x) + 0 = g(x) </math>
sols_html:
Because \(e^{x}\) is its own derivative, our anti-derivative for the function \(e^{3-x}\) will probably be very similar to the original function. In fact, \(F(x) = - e^{3-x}\) will work; you can check by differentiating using the chain rule to get

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle F'(x) = -(-e^{3-x}) = e^{3-x} = f(x)\end{aligned}\]

This is one anti-derivative. To find another one, we can simply add a constant to the anti-derivative shown above, say \(F_2(x) = -e^{3-x} + 5\). When we differentiate, the constant will disappear, giving us the same derivative as before.
sols_latex:
Because $e^{x}$ is its own derivative, our anti-derivative for the
function $e^{3-x}$ will probably be very similar to the original
function. In fact, $F(x) = - e^{3-x}$ will work; you can check by
differentiating using the chain rule to get

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
F'(x) = -(-e^{3-x}) = e^{3-x} = f(x)
\end{align*}

This is one anti-derivative. To find another one, we can simply add a
constant to the anti-derivative shown above, say
$F_2(x) = -e^{3-x} + 5$. When we differentiate, the constant will
disappear, giving us the same derivative as before.
sols_raw:
Because <math>e^{x}</math> is its own derivative, our anti-derivative for the function <math>e^{3-x}</math> will probably be very similar to the original function.  In fact, <math>F(x) = - e^{3-x}</math> will work; you can check by differentiating using the chain rule to get

:<math> \displaystyle
F'(x) = -(-e^{3-x}) = e^{3-x} = f(x)
</math>  

This is one anti-derivative.  To find another one, we can simply add a constant to the anti-derivative shown above, say <math>F_2(x) = -e^{3-x} + 5</math>.  When we differentiate, the constant will disappear, giving us the same derivative as before.
statement_html:
An antiderivative of a function \(f\) is a function F satisfying

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle F'(x) = f(x)\end{aligned}\]

for all x. Find two antiderivatives of the function

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle e^{3-x}.\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
An ''antiderivative'' of a function &fnof; is a function ''F'' satisfying
:<math> \displaystyle
F'(x) = f(x)
</math>
for all ''x''. Find two antiderivatives of the function 

: <math>\displaystyle e^{3-x}</math>.
